key_points: Oil prices rebounded following a ship running aground and blocking the Suez Canal.
The incident provided a reprieve amidst a downturn in the oil market, with prices having dropped to the lowest since early February.
Oil futures in New York increased by 1% after the grounding incident.
Oil prices have fallen more than 12% in less than two weeks, influenced by softening physical demand and the unwinding of long positions.
The prompt timespread for global Brent crude has entered a bearish structure, indicating near-dated contracts are cheaper than later-dated ones.
U.S. crude inventories reportedly rose by almost 3 million barrels last week.
OPEC+ may face pressure to address the recent plunge in oil prices at their next meeting.
Despite the recent decline, crude prices are still up almost 20% this year, with expectations that fuel consumption will increase as COVID-19 vaccinations accelerate.
The blockage of the Suez Canal by the Ever Given ship has caused a gridlock of at least 100 vessels.
Approximately 10% of total seaborne oil trade goes through the Suez Canal, but any disruption is expected to be temporary.
spokespersons: Will Sungchil Yun (Senior Commodities Analyst, VI Investment Corp.)
Warren Patterson (Head of Commodities Strategy, ING Group)
